content.text: State and explain what happens to the kinetic energy of the box during the first 6.0s of its descent
State and explain what happens to the gravitational potential energy of the box during the first 6.0s
Use the graph in Fig. 1.2 to determine the speed of the object when the object is moving with a constant speed
State the size of the resultant vertical force on the box when it is falling at a constant speed
Use the graph in Fig. 1.2 to determine the distance travelled by the box during the first 6.0s
distance travelled in first 6.0s =   .........  m
Without calculation, describe how Fig. 1.2 shows that the deceleration of the box is greater than the acceleration of the box
Fig. 1.1 shows a box dropped from an aeroplane. The box contains supplies
A parachute is attached to the box. The parachute is opened when the time is 6.0 s
The graph in Fig. 1.2 shows the vertical speed of the box as it falls
Calculate the volume of the stone
Another stone has a mass of \(98.4 \text{g}\). The volume of this stone is \(41.0 \text{cm}^3\)
Calculate the density of the stone
The stone with a mass of \(98.4 \text{g}\) has a weight of \(0.984 \text{N}\)
Explain the difference between mass and weight
Fig. 2.1 shows a measuring cylinder containing water
Fig. 2.2 shows the same measuring cylinder after a stone has been lowered into it
Fig. 2.2
Calculate the moment of the \(5.2 \text{N}\) force about the pivot and show that its value is close to \(30 \text{Ncm}\)
The beam is balanced. Calculate force \(P\)
Fig. 3.1 shows the forces acting on a uniform balanced beam. The beam is pivoted at its centre
State the names of the parts of the power station labelled A and B
part A
part B
Geothermal energy is one source of renewable energy
State two other sources of renewable energy
State two environmental advantages, other than being renewable, of a geothermal power station compared to a coal-fired power station
Fig. 4.1 shows an outline of the main parts of a geothermal power station used to generate electricity. Some parts of the power station are labelled
The mass of the metal block is \(1.6 \text{kg}\)
Calculate the weight of the metal block
weight =   .........  N
Calculate the pressure on the flat surface due to the metal block
pressure =   .........  N/cmÂ²
In an experiment, the metal block is heated and the temperature of the metal block increases by \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
State the effect, if any, of the temperature increase on:
1. the volume of the metal block
2. the mass of the metal block
3. the density of the metal block
Fig. 5.1 shows a metal block on a flat surface
On Fig. 6.1, label the angle of incidence at A. Use the letter X to label the angle.
State the name of the process which occurs at A
State the name given to the dashed line at A
On Fig. 6.1, one of the angles at B is \(62^{\circ}\). State the value of the angle labelled P
State the name of the process which occurs at B
On Fig. 6.1, draw the path of the ray of red light as it travels from C into the air
Fig. 6.1 shows the path of a ray of red light through a glass block in air
The critical angle for the red light as it travels from glass into air is \(43^{\circ}\)
Give the label letter \(\mathbf{P}, \mathbf{Q}, \mathbf{R}, \mathbf{S}\) or \(\mathbf{T}\) for the arrow which represents:
1. the amplitude of the wave
2. the wavelength of the wave
A student stands next to a pond and observes water waves on its surface. She counts 12 complete waves passing a point in the pond in a time of 8.0 s
Calculate the frequency of the water waves
frequency =   .........  \(Hz\)
Fig. 7.1 shows a transverse wave. Describe the difference between transverse and longitudinal waves
You may draw a labelled diagram
Fig. 7.1 shows a transverse wave
Describe an experiment to identify the pattern and direction of magnetic field lines around a bar magnet as shown in Fig. 8.1
You may add to Fig. 8.1 as part of your answer
State a material that can be used to make a permanent bar magnet
Fig. 8.1 shows the magnetic field pattern around a bar magnet
The student wants to reverse the direction of the force on the wire
State **one** change that reverses the direction of the force on the wire
The student increases the separation of the poles of the permanent magnets
State and explain how increasing the separation affects the force on the current-carrying wire
A student uses two bar magnets to create a uniform magnetic field. He places a current-carrying wire at right angles to the magnetic field, as shown in Fig. 8.2
There is a force on the current-carrying wire
When the circuit is in a cool room, the voltmeter reading is \(5.6\mathrm{V}\) and the ammeter reading is \(0.040\mathrm{A}\)
Calculate the resistance of the thermistor
resistance of thermistor =   .........  \(\Omega\)
The temperature of the thermistor increases and the buzzer turns on
State and explain how the increase in temperature affects the current in the thermistor
Suggest a possible use for the circuit shown in Fig. 9.1
Fig. 9.1 shows an electric circuit
State the hazard of using mains equipment with damaged insulation
Describe how a fuse protects a mains electrical appliance
The laptop computer uses a transformer to change the voltage of the mains electricity supply
The input (primary) voltage is 120V
The input (primary) coil has 2000 turns and the output (secondary) coil has 200 turns
Calculate the output (secondary) voltage from the transformer
output (secondary) voltage =   .........  V
State the name of the material used in the core of the transformer
A student uses a laptop computer. The student notices that the cable connecting the power adapter for a laptop to the mains electricity supply is damaged as shown in Fig. 10.1
Determine the numbers of electrons, protons and neutrons in an atom of carbon-12 and the numbers of electrons, protons and neutrons in an atom of carbon-14
Complete Table 11.1
Fig. 11.3 shows the decay curve for a sample of carbon-14
Use the graph to determine the half-life of carbon-14
half-life =   .........  years
Carbon-12 is a stable isotope of carbon. Its nuclide notation is shown in Fig. 11.1
Carbon-14 is an unstable isotope of carbon. Its nuclide notation is shown in Fig. 11.2
